On Tuesday, the former football player attempted to paint his Democratic opponent, Sen. Raphael Warnock, as soft on crime by posting a photo of what appears to be a special deputy sheriff card reportedly given to him by the Cobb County Sheriff‚Äôs Department. Except the card isn‚Äôt really bonafide.

In his tweet on the subject, the first-time candidate he was ‚Äúproud to serve the blue,‚Äù in reference to law enforcement, and included an image of a certificate in which he was described as an ‚Äúhonorary‚Äù agent.
But Walker‚Äôs pride notwithstanding, voluntarily renewing interest in one of his more glaring vulnerabilities was unwise.
As we discussed a few months ago, Walker repeatedly lied to the public about having a law enforcement background. In one speech, for example, Walker told a U.S. Army audience about a 2001 incident. ‚ÄúI worked in law enforcement, so I had a gun,‚Äù he claimed. In 2017, he specifically said, ‚ÄúI work with the Cobb County Police Department.‚Äù
The evidence suggests otherwise. The Cobb County Police Department told the Atlanta Journal-Constitution it has no record of Walker working with the department.
